title: PyRoomStudio: A 3D Acoustic Room Simulator
description: An ongoing project to create a 3D room simulator for acoustic research and education. Built as a GUI wrapper for the PyRoomAcoustics library, with audio simulation and rendering functionality using PyGame and PyOpenGL. Features include real-time audio rendering, room geometry manipulation, and source/receiver placement. GitHub link will be provided soon, as we're working to make the repository open source.

title: Multi-Modal Diffusion Project
technologies: Python, Jupyter Notebook, Diffusers, Transformers, PyTorch, Data Visualization
description: An ongoing research project exploring alignment in latent features between image and audio generative models. Originally started as a course project for CS 598 GMA: Generative Audio Models, and now being expanded into a larger research endeavor. We're working on writing a paper to submit to a conference, so documentation/code will be made public at a later date.

title: Pips/Dominoes Puzzle Framework
description: A vanilla Python3 framework for solving and generating puzzles based on the NYTGames "Pips" puzzle. Includes a webscraper for collecting and formatting puzzles from the NYTGames website.

title: Untitled Stealth Conversational AI Project
collaborators: Mark Bauer, Tyler Lee, Quinn Ouyang
description: An ongoing stealth project focused on building a real-time conversation agent with desktop screen context. More details to come at a later date.

title: Thesis: Text Recaptioning for Audio Diffusion Models
description: M.S. Thesis on output variability in audio diffusion models. Investigates the difference in output quality and diversity when using reworded prompts for text-to-audio generation. Experiments are performed using the AudioLDM and MusicGen models, with a focus on sound effect generation.

links.text: GitHub (a little messy... will clean up later)

title: Generative AI as (in) Art
technologies: ChatGPT, DALLÂ·E 3, Midjourney, Stable Diffusion, Google Gemini
description: Course work and final project completed for ARTS 444: Generative AI as (in) Art. Explored the use of generative AI tools in the context of art-making, with a focus on ethical considerations and the implications of AI-generated content in contemporary art practices. My work culminated in the final project "Statistically Realistic Music", which I wrote about in the blog post linked below.

title: Tileify
description: Refined script for generating Discord-compatible image/GIF emojis from larger files. Originally designed by Rutvik Choudhary, I improved the codebase to include better error handling, support for more file types, and a more user-friendly command-line interface.

title: Deep in the Web
description: Research project for CS 412: Intro to Data Mining. A multi-network analysis of data from the Child Mind Institute's Health Brain Network (HBN) dataset., proving the efficacy of using machine learning models to predict Problematic Internet Use (PIU) in children and adolescents.

title: I still see (Bad) Shadows in my Room: Analyzing and Detecting Lighting Inconsistencies in AI-Generated Images
collaborators: Dwip Dalal, Adheesh Juvekar, Jiachen Tu
description: Research project for CS 543: Computer Vision. Analyzes the prevalence of lighting and shadow inconsistencies in AI-generated images, and implements a machine learning model to detect said inconsistencies. Lighting and shadow information was captured with DiffusionLight, a generative model for inpainting image information on a chrome sphere.

title: LISZT: Lightweight Interface for Supercollider Zen Tasking
description: A terminal-based interface for programming and running SuperCollider tasks using the SC3nb library. This project aims to provide a REPL-like approach for live coding and playback outside of the SuperCollider IDE. Built as a final project for MUS 499C: Creating Audio Coding with SuperCollider, taught by Eli Fieldsteel.

title: A Case for Bayesian Grading
description: Research project for CS 500: Topics in Computer Education Research. Simulating student grades as bayesian probabilities for analysis on trustworthiness. A combination of proctored (UIUC CBTF) and non-proctored scores were used in the simulation process. Accepted to SIGCSE Virtual 2024!

title: Optical Music Recognition for LilyPond File Generation
description: Graduate project for CS 444: Machine Learning for Computer Vision. Analysis of state-of-the-art work in Optical Music Recognition (OMR) with respect to several digital music notation formats. LilyPond is deemed to be a reasonable format for use in OMR given its current structure and underlying functionality for batch exporting.

title: Nearest Neighbor Classification for Classical Image Upsampling
description: Research project for CS 545: Machine Learning for Signal Processing. Explores the use of K-Nearest-Neighbors Interpolation for the purpose of image upsampling. Implementation expanded to include dynamic aspect ratio upsampling and selective upsampling to reduce computation time for images with solid-color regions.

title: Old Personal Website
description: Built with Hugo and designed using the XMIN theme.

title: Undergraduate Capstone: Transcribing Monophonic Audio with Deep-Learning Data
description: Combined senior capstone project with Kevin Zhou. Our main goal was to implement a machine-learning model for rudimentary conversion of raw audio recordings into readable sheet music. I created the database of examples to be recorded and handled the business side of the study, and Kevin put together the webapp SingSong for collecting recording data.

title: Absentea
collaborators: Majeed Akinlusi, Zeyang "Hans" Zhang, Kevin Zhou
description: Final project for CS 411; database webapp designed for comparing schedules and absences between members of an organization or group. Inspiration taken from scheduling sites like When2meet and Doodle.

title: DISSCO
description: DISSCO, or Digital Instrument for Sound Synthesis and Composition, is a Linux-based program combining music composition and sound synthesis for the easier creation of stochastic and non-stochastic music.

title: Disklavier Echo Effect
description: "This is a course project for MUS 305 at the University of Illinois Champaign-Urbana, under the course direction of Dr. Heinrich Taube. This project aims to simulate an 'echo' effect on a Yamaha Disklavier piano, on up to 16 key simulatenously, with repetitions and diminishing of echo sound up to the performer. The program runs using the musx library and uses threading to run real-time outputs to a Yamaha Disklavier."

title: Pan-Lang
collaborators: Renzo Ledesma, Katie Saunders, Kevin Zhou
description: Second prize winner at PYGHACK 2020: a food pantry webapp designed providing translated lists and descriptions to patrons of Champaign and Urbana-area foodbanks.

title: Spotigraph
collaborators: Beth Fineberg, Cale Wolf, Kevin Zhou
description: Final project for CS 225: Data Structures. Makes use of graph traversal algorithms to find the kth degrees (nearest artist) to a given Spotify artist.

title: WarioWare!
description: Final project for CS 125: Intro to Computer Science, (now CS 124: Intro to Computer Science I). Android app consisting of several minigames in the style of Nintendo's WarioWare. Players are rewarded with coins which they can use to purchase trophies (Bitmojis of the CS 125 course staff). This app made the list of "Impressive Projects" at the CS 125 Final Project Fair.

title: Early Work
description: A fair amount of HTML/CSS programming, GameMaker projects, and a really basic Minecraft mod in Java. My high school didn't offer any computer science courses at the time, so I picked up Java and C++ through summer college courses before entering UIUC.
